This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE PRISONER AT LARGE: A COMEDY. IN TWO ACTS. AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL IN THE HAY-MARKET, WITH UNIVERSAL APPLAUSE.

Written by JOHN O'KEEFFE, AUTHOR OF TONY LUMPKIN IN TOWN; THE SON-IN-LAW; THE DEAD ALIVE; THE AGREEABLE SURPRISE; THE POSITIVE MAN; THE CASTLE OF ANDALUSIA; THE YOUNG QUAKER; THE BIRTH-DAY, OR THE PRINCE OF ARRAGON; THE POOR SOLDIER; PEEPING TOM; FONTAINBLEAU, OR OUR WAY IN FRANCE; THE BEGGAR ON HORSEBACK; OMAI; LOVE IN A CAMP, OR PATRICK IN PRUSSIA; SIEGE OF CURZOLA; THE FARMER, &c. &c. &c.
LONDON: Printed for G. G. J. and J. ROBINSON, Paternoſter-Row. M DCC LXXXVIII.

div.head: TO Mr. EDWIN.
div.p: WITHOUT your Concurrence, or even previous Knowledge, I take the Liberty to inſcribe the PRISONER AT LARGE to you; a Trifle, where ſo much is owing: But having hitherto diſpoſed of my Right in my Copies, to the Proprietors of the Theatres, this is my firſt Opportunity of making a public Acknowledgment of the very great Advantages which my Dramatic Pieces have derived from your happy and juſt Conception of my Meaning, your induſtrious Application to the Study of my Characters, and your powerful Comic Abilities in the Performance of them.
With the moſt ſincere Wiſhes that you, in the ſucceſsful Purſuit of your Profeſſion, may long continue, as you are, the Delight of the Public, and the higheſt Reſpect for your Talents,

closer.signed: I am, Dear SIR, Your much obliged and very humble Servant, JOHN O'KEEFFE.

div.head: Dramatis Perſonae.
div.p: SCENE in the Weſt of Ireland. Time—A Night and Morning.

div.head: THE PRISONER AT LARGE: A COMEDY.
ACT I.
div.stage: SCENE I. A Garden to Lord ESMOND's Houſe, a Gate in the Back leading to the Road.
Enter FRILL and MUNS, quarrelling; MARY interpoſing.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: CONCEITED fop!

sp.speaker: Frill.
sp.p: Impertinent ſavage!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Gentlemen—

sp.speaker: Frill.
sp.p: 'Pon my honour I ſhall pink you.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: And by my fiſt I'll thump you.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: But, my dear rival lovers, my town fop, and my country beau; ſilly to quarrel about me; for when one gets thump'd, and t'other pink'd as you call it, probably I may have neither of you.

sp.speaker: Frill.
sp.p: Didn't you confeſs, my little Spaniſh guitar tickled your heart?

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: And, my ſweet, didn't you own that my great French horn rouſed your ſoul?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Yes; but 'pon my reputation, gents, I have not yet determined whether I ever was rouſed or tickled.

sp.speaker: RACHEL
sp.p: Mary!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: My miſtreſs! Coming, madam.

sp.speaker: COUNT
sp.p: Frill!

sp.speaker: Frill.
sp.p: My maſter! Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Old DOWDLE, without.
sp.p: You Muns! Why Muns!

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: My Maſter! zounds! Sir—I'm here—I'm there.—Mary, don't ſtay with that fellow.—Coming, Sir.

sp.speaker: Frill.
sp.p: I can't bear to leave 'em together.—Coming, Sir.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Mary, ſee where's Miſs Adelaide.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Yes, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Count Frip.
sp.p: My riding hat and ſwitch cane.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p:
Here, Muns! you loitering curs'd vagabond—what are you at? Call, call, call!—Deſire Yemon to get the horſes ready. (Exit Muns.) Ay, Count, ſince my maſter, the lord of this houſe, has been ſo unlucky as to loſe his eſtate, and you and your friends in Paris have
been lucky enough to win it, now I am your ſteward; and as they ſent you over here to Ireland, to collect the rents, to pay his Lordſhip's bonds to them, I'll go now about and make the tenants pay them into your hands, on condition you marry my daughter Rachel here.

sp.speaker: Count Frip.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: You will not. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Count Frip.
sp.p: But all de clown of tenant, when I did go to gather in de l'argent, did throw de mud and ſtone at my head, ſpoil my curl, knock o' my hair out of my buckle; ma foi, call me Jack Frog. Now, Mademoiſelle, am I like dat Jacky de Frog?

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Fools! They never ſaw their landlord, Lord Eſmond, ſince he was a boy. No, he ſpent his time and money flying over Italy and Germany, like a wild gooſe, till he's got himſelf now coop'd up in a priſon at Paris! Ha, ha, ha! Come, Count, I hope to bring all the tenants to reaſon—but that ſneering raſcal Jack Connor—Daughter, I inſiſt you'll never ſpeak to him.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Not I, Sir—till you go out. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Here, you Muns! (calling.)

sp.speaker: Count Frip.
sp.p: Frill.

div.stage: Enter FRILL, who whiſpers the Count.

sp.speaker: Frill.
sp.p: A ſervant without from one Mr. Nugent, from Paris.

sp.speaker: Count Frip.
sp.p: Nugent! One of our club—I come. Monſieur, excuſe moi pour un moment.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Sir, the horſes are ready.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p:
Rachel, as 'tis late, we ſha'n't be home
to night—the Count and I'll take a bed where we can—ſome of the tenants—

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: This is charming! (aſide.) Dear papa, ſure you won't ſleep out all night!

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Buſineſs.—You Muns. (apart.)

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: You'll let me know if Jack Connor meets my daughter, whilſt I am away. There's a retaining fee, you dog.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: I will, Sir. (apart.)

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Muns, run and tell Jack Connor to come here to me as ſoon as my father's out of ſight. There's ſomething to drink our health by the way. (Gives him money.)

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: I will, Miſs.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Now you'll be on the watch; I may depend on you. Apar

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: You may, Sir. (apart.)

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: You won't fail?

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: I won't.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Mind, don't ſtir out. (To Muns apart, and exit.)

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Not a leg.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: You'll run now to Jack Connor?

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Every foot.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: My dear Jack Connor, I love him more than ever for his fidelity to my Lord; and ſurely the man of honour and integrity can never prove a faithleſs lover. (Enter Adelaide.) Ah, you ſly one! you come down here to the country on a viſit to me, yet prefer birds and groves to all we can invent to amuſe you.—Now is n't it love?

sp.speaker: Adelaide.
sp.p: My dear Rachel, I'd make you my confidante, but you're ſuch a giddy creature.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: I! Me? Ha, ha, ha! What would I give that you had a lover!

sp.speaker: Adelaide.
sp.p: I had.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: O precious! Who is he?

sp.speaker: Adelaide.
sp.p: Let theſe tears tell you my lover is no more.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Dear me!

sp.speaker: Adelaide.
sp.p: 'Tis now ten years ſince I ſaw my Nugent at Montpellier.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Ten years! You conſtant ſoul!

sp.speaker: Adelaide.
sp.p: I was ſcarce fifteen: his fortune was doubtful; my father forbid our intercourſe—my Nugent was ſeized by ruffians (I could never find the cauſe), and carried up to Paris; but have ſince been aſſured, by my father, of his death.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Lord! had I known, I ſhould not have revived a painful idea.—Come, I muſt keep up your ſpirits. My father won't be home all night, and I've ſent for my dear Jack Connor, to ſup with us. Come, now, I wiſh I dare be angry with my father, for joining this ſharping Count againſt his own maſter, Lord Eſmond: no wonder, for his mother, the old lady, not to reſt in her grave. Adelaide, as ſure as I live, I heard the ghoſt ſing laſt night in the Belvedere room—the ſweeteſt voice!

sp.speaker: Adelaide.
sp.p: Very ſtrange! I've now ſat up purpoſely three nights, but I've neither ſeen nor heard this wonder.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Oh, but my dear, the poor dead lady is certainly diſturb'd by the misfortunes of her ſon, Lord Eſmond:—it muſt be ſhe, for the apparition is dreſs'd exactly like her picture that hangs in the room where it walks.

sp.speaker: Adelaide.
sp.p: All fancy.—Ah! if the dead were ſuffer'd to reviſit us, I ſhould be comforted by my Nugent.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Come, we muſt have no more thoughts of dead lovers:—you ſhall hear my living lover rattle, court, and ſing at our little party; we'll be ſo jolly.—Come along.

div.stage: SCENE, a fine Country. Sun going down. Lord ESMOND's Houſe at a Diſtance; at the Side JACK CONNOR's Houſe.
Enter Lord ESMOND (plainly dreſs'd), TRAP and SERVANT.

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: Then the Count will meet me?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: You call'd me Nugent?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I did, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: Very well; take the horſes back to the inn. Well, Trap, I've been your priſoner ten years, and your ſuffering me to come here from Paris is a ſtretch of good nature.—Yonder's my houſe: here am I in the centre of my own eſtate, and, thanks to fortune, not maſter of one foot of land.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Night's coming on, and not a roof here will ſhelter us. In view of your houſe I can't get a mug of beer. (Muſic and laughing without.) Country people leaving off work: I'll ſee if I can't get a drop amongſt 'em.—But, my Lord, don't run away, for if I hav'n't you to bring back with me to jail, I ſhall get hang'd.—Hollo! neighbours.

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: Somewhere here ſtood (looking) the cottage of poor old Connor—a good houſe; he thrives; I'm glad on't. His ſon Jack was my little play-fellow,

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: Ah, merry be your hearts.—Good-night, neighbours.—All going to their comfortable homes; whilſt I—this bachelor's life is plaguy ſtupid—I will marry my little Rachel.

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: Hollo! Friend, d'ye know where I can get a bed?

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: I've two or three ſpare beds in my houſe here.

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: One will do for me.

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: Then one you ſhall have, on one condition tho'—that you drink one jug of ale with me after ſupper.

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: Supper, and a jug of ale! Your terms are rather ſevere to a hungry, thirſty, weary, traveller.

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: Thirſty! Oh! (aſide.) Phelim.

div.stage: Enter PHELIM, to whom Jack Connor whiſpers.

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: You ſhall have a traveller's welcome to the houſe of Jack Connor.

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: 'Tis he! the companion of my youth.

div.stage: (Re-enter Phelim with a jug of ale and drinking horn.)

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: I'll fill for you, Sir—Come—

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: The good-natur'd boy ripen'd into the benevolent man.

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: My firſt toaſt, always a bumper: Here's freedom to my landlord, Lord Eſmond.

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: Pray where is my Lord now?

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: In priſon, near ten years; and I fear for life.

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, Sir; but when I toaſt my friend in diſtreſs, I mix my drink with water.

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: Affectionate fellow! (aſide.) But I've heard ſay, my Lord is rather a diſſipated worthleſs ſort of character.

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: What's that? (fiercely.) You're welcome to what my houſe affords; but ſup by yourſelf, for I'll never ſit at one board with him who could ſlander the man I eſteem and honour.

div.stage: Enter MUNS, and whiſpers Jack Connor.

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: Her father out? and ſent for me? My kind Rachel! If I'had but Father Frank, now—he might—Muns, how go on the Count's affairs?

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: A myſtery there.—But (takes a horn of ale) I'll get to the bottom on't. (drinks.) Now I'm prim'd for love or war: if Frill dare but look crooked, or Mary but frown—oh! how I'll bang him, and touzle her.

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: As I find all here have loſt every remembrance of my perſon, I'll venture up to the caſtle, and ſee the Count, in my character of Nugent.

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: Phelim, let this gentleman want for nothing till I come home. Your hand, Sir; I was angry, but you're a ſtranger; perhaps in neceſſity—and my doors ſhall never be ſhut againſt the weary traveller.

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: You are an honeſt fellow, that I'll be ſworn for.

div.stage: SCENE, an Apartment in Lord ESMOND's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Frill.
sp.p: I ſuſpect here's ſomething going forward againſt my maſter.—Here comes Muns and Mary.—See—kiſs—oh the traitreſs!

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: True. Ha, ha, ha! But, Mary my dear, how could you liſten to ſuch a cur as Frill?

sp.speaker: Frill.
sp.p: I'm a cur! Oh you puppy.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Frill is a creature—but really ſince this ghoſt has appeared, the houſe is ſo frightful that any company is acceptable.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: That for the ghoſt! To night we are to have a jolly little party—Huſh, my dear, (with joy)—Jack Connor's coming to Miſs Rachel, I'm with you, and cook is preparing a nice bit of ſupper for us all, tol, lol!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: A ſupper! delightful!

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Old maſter don't come home to night, and we'll be ſo merry, tol, lol.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Charming! then I'll go ſuperintend ſupper.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: And I'll make Tooten the black, my pupil, prepare his horn.—Oh, how ſweetly we play'd on the water yeſterday!—They may talk of fine views, and viſtos, and beauties of nature; but 'tis to hear the divine echos of my horn, that brings the gentlefolks all the way from Cork, and even Dublin, down here to the lake of Killarney. But now for ſupper.

div.stage: MUNS and MARY placing tables and a ſcreen between.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: There! the lovers ſha'n't be overlook'd by us, ha! ha! ha! Here Tooten and I'll ſit and take our pleaſure—while they mingle lips, we'll jingle glaſſes.—Oh how I love to ſee good cheer going forward!

sp.speaker: Frill.
sp.p: So, here's rare doings in the old gentleman's abſence; maſter and I bubbled by ſuch clowns as Muns and Jack Connor—oh revenge!

sp.speaker: Frill.
sp.p: Oh choice luck! Here comes the old codger home unexpectedly.—Such a hobble as I'll bring 'em into. Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Oh my bones! Who's that I ſee there? What, are they all gone to bed? Well I'll go too, and not diſturb any body.

sp.speaker: Frill.
sp.p: What, Sir, go to bed without your ſupper? the nice ſupper that Miſs Rachel has prepared for you?

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Hey! what is all this?

sp.speaker: Frill.
sp.p: The table laid for your ſupper, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Why who knew I was coming home?

sp.speaker: Frill.
sp.p: Miſs Rachel, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Eh! then ſhe knows I had a fall from my horſe?

sp.speaker: Frill.
sp.p: The devil a word of it. (aſide) Oh yes, Sir, Mary told her that.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Mary! who told Mary?

sp.speaker: Frill.
sp.p: Oh, Sir—ſhe ſaw you, Sir, as ſhe was taking a walk.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: She took a devil of a long walk then; for I fell ſix miles off.

sp.speaker: Frill.
sp.p: That was a great fall indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Eh?

sp.speaker: Frill.
sp.p: Walk—yes, Sir—ride—Sir—Mary was riding too—the evening being fine, Miſs Rachel gave her leave to go ſee her brother.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Mary?

sp.speaker: Frill.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; Muns rode before her.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: After my orders to ſtay at home on the watch! Before Mary? Then I ſuppoſe the raſcal took my cheſnut pad?

sp.speaker: Frill.
sp.p: Don't ſay I told you—but I fancy he did—they wou'd not wiſh you to know it, Sir—they'll all deny it to you.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Mary!—he—indeed I heard a woman ſquall.

sp.speaker: Frill.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, ſhe ſaid ſhe ſquall'd.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Then perhaps 'twas ſhe ſent the 'pothecary to me.

sp.speaker: Frill.
sp.p: It was, Sir.—One lie has drawn me into a dozen.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: A buſy ſlut! He was a farrier—call'd himſelf a ſurgeon, tho' he was a farrier; for the fellow out with a ſteam, up with my leg, and ſwore he'd bleed me in the fetlock.—Where's your maſter?

sp.speaker: Frill.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, didn't he come home with you?

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p:
No, he ſaid ſomebody from France was to meet him at an inn three miles off, he, he!—But I'm glad my daughter had ſo much thought as to provide a morſel for me.—Oh what happineſs, after all one's croſſes abroad, to come to one's own home, when one's children
and ſervants are ſo attentive to render it agreedable!—Muns! (calls) Where's this curſed fellow, with his galloping my horſes about the country? Frill, ſhall I trouble you to help me on with my gown, and then I can come and ſit down to my ſupper in comfort.

sp.speaker: Frill.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.—Oh what a rare hobble I ſhall bring them into, ha, ha, ha!

div.stage: Enter RACHEL, ADELAIDE, and JACK CONNOR.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: And there now is my old papa, trotting from cottage to barn, like a cunning little exciſeman, with his green book under his arm, and his pen ſtuck in his wig.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: But why won't Miſs Adelaide give us her company?

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: You muſt.

sp.speaker: Adelaide.
sp.p: My dear, ſuffer me to go to reſt, if I can reſt.—The death of nay Nugent, the miſfortunes of Lord Eſmond—tho' I never ſaw him—It may ſeem an affectation of ſenſibility—I can't account for it, but I feel ſomething inexpreſſibly horrid hanging over me, ever ſince you ſhow'd me the old lady's clothes.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Sure!

sp.speaker: Adelaide.
sp.p: Not a night I don't dream I'm rummaging her clothes-preſs in the haunted room, as you call it.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Well, my dear, if you will retire, ſuffer Jack to ſee you acroſs the gallery.

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: Ay, Miſs, under my guard, ſhow me the ghoſt that dare affront you.

div.stage: Enter MARY with ſupper, which ſhe puts on the table.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: There, Miſs.—Let's ſee, I muſt bring another bottle; for your lover is a good fellow, and a good fellow deſerves a good bottle.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: I wiſh Jack Connor wou'd make haſte. (begins to carve) Ha, ha, ha! My little dad, if he knew what we were at here now.

div.stage: Enter DOWDLE, in an undreſs. Rachel carves with her back to him as he enters.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Yes, my poor father's faſt aſleep by this, in ſome peaceful cottage. Ha, ha, ha! I did not care if he had a taſte of this turkey; I know the old lad likes a bit o' the merry-thought.—How long my dearee ſtays!—Is that you?— (Speaks without looking round) Eh! you've been giving her a kiſs, I ſuppoſe—come, whilſt its hot; ſit down, you fooliſh fellow.

div.stage: Dowdle comes round, and ſits down oppoſite to her.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Dowdle.
sp.p: What's the matter with you?

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Sir, I—I—I thought it was the ghoſt.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Why, did you invite the ghoſt to ſupper?

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: If Jack returns we're undone. (aſide) Lord, Sir, who expected you?

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Indeed I ſhould not have been home to night, but for the tumble.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: What tumble, Sir?

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Sure you—oh true, I wa'n't to know ſhe let Muns gallop my horſes about the road. (aſide) Well, ha, ha! I forgive you and him, ſince it has procured me ſo good a ſupper. Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Forgive us! Then, Sir, you know all?

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I'm not angry—call the fellow.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: O precious! Then, Sir, you'll let him ſup with us?

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Sup! what your ſervant?

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: True, Sir, I am his miſtreſs, and he loves me dearly.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Who, Muns?

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Muns!

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: If your Muns dare to ſit down at a table with me, I'll knock the ſcoundrel to the devil.

div.stage: Enter MUNS and BLACK, who ſit at the other table.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Now, Tooten, don't look towards the lovers—here we'll ſit, play, and take our glaſſes. (They drink) Now up with Black Sloven.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Hey!

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: How d'ye like that, my lad o' wax?

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Eh!

div.stage: (Surpriſed, ſoftly riſes and peeps over the ſcreen, which he had placed between the two tables; at the ſame time Dowdle turns up his face.)

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: If I could prevent Jack Connor from coming in.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Here's two bottles for the jolly dog.

div.stage: (Sets them on the table, where Muns ſits.)

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Go give it to the jolly dog yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: (goes round the ſcreen, and ſeeing Dowdle, ſcreams) Ah!

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Curſe your ſqualling! I believe it was you that frighten'd my horſe.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Me!

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Where the devil did you pick up ſuch an apothecary?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I pick up an apothecary! Sir, I'd have you to know—

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: He was a farrier (enraged); and, Sirrah, the next time you take the road—

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: I take the road!

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: So you muſt go on the pad!

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: I go on the pad! Oh Lord!

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: You ſcoundrel! cantering about.—Where's the pillion?

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Mary, fetch my maſter the pillow.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: So, Sirrah, ſhe's in love with you?

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—eh Mary? ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: And you muſt ſit down and ſup with me?

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Eh! well—thank ye, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Fine! Hadn't you better aſk the black-a-moor? (Ironically)

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Tooten, ſit down, boy.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Get along, you infernal impudent ſon of a—

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Oh Lord, he's mad!

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Where's my ſaddle, you villain?

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: His ſaddle! Going to ride this tim night—yes, the devil's got into him.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: I'll beat him out of you, you damn'd rogue.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: The ghoſt has bit him—Oh.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: A knave!

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: This old manſion has ſo many windings, I thought I ſhould never have found my way back again.—Come, ſit down, my dear.—Zounds!

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Stop the fellow—thieves—

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I wonder if Miſs Rachel's gone to bed.—Jack Connor muſt have ſlipped out when he heard maſter ſcolding us—Yes, I hear him locking the great gate.—Near one o'clock—I wiſh I was in my own room—I dread croſſing that diſmal gallery: if I meet any thing I ſhould die, I'm ſo frighten'd. O Lord, what's that?

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Tis I, my dear.—D'ye think maſter ſaw Jack Connor?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I hope not; but I can't conceive how he got off.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: No matter, as he wa'n't ſeen we're ſafe.—But here's a ſtrange gentleman, I ſaw him juſt now at Jack Connor's—knock'd at the poſtern, and aſk'd for a bed, as he's benighted, and—

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: The deuce! Were you mad, to let a ſtranger in at this time of night? He may be a white boy.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Looke, Mary, I let him in out of good nature—let thoſe that are ill natured turn him out.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p:
Why 'twould be cruel indeed; only maſter's ſo croſs.—Stop—I've a thought—the fineſt opportunity!—Let's put him to ſleep in
the haunted room; as he don't know on't he won't be afraid, and if the ghoſt walks he'll certainly ſpeak to it, and then—

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Why yes, if it is our dead lady, ſhe may tell him what diſturbs her, then may be ſhe'll vaniſh, and trouble the houſe no more—I like it hugely.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Where have you left the gentleman?

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: In the lodge. Come—

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: You need n't run away from a body.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Ah! how loving theſe women are, when they ſtand in need of our protection. Hem! (ſwaggers) Eh! bleſs me! tol, lol, lol.

div.stage: SCENE, an antique Apartment. A Lady's Picture hanging over the Chimney.
Enter MUNS and MARY, with lights, introducing Lord Eſmond.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: This is the room, Sir.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.stage: (in terror, yet trying to conceal it)
sp.p: Yes, Sir, this is the room, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: I'm very much obliged to you.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: The bed's in the alcove, Sir.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Well, Mary, put on the ſheets, and air it well for the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Can't you?

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Pſha!

div.stage: (apart—each urging the other to go in.)

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Sir, the bed is very well air'd.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, it has been laid in, not above—eight years ago. (aſide) Go—(to Mary, who with much heſitation and terror goes into the alcove)

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: The gentleman of the houſe is gone to reſt?

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, the gentleman of the houſe reſted in priſon theſe ten years—

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: Indeed! Poor gentleman.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, he's a lord; the cards and dice have left him a very poor gentleman—but my maſter, his ſteward, is now quietly ſnoring.

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: Then I ſhall return him thanks in the morning.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, you may as well not thank him, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: Oh then 'tis entirely to you I'm obliged?

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: As I was left by the man of the houſe, when you ſaw me, but for your humanity, I muſt have lain in the fields all night—Here.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: As I did'n't buy my humanity, I never will ſell it.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: There, Sir, the bed's ready—Lord!—ſo frighten'd!—thought I ſhould never get done.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Huſh! huſh! (apart) Sir, we'll leave you a light, Sir, and you may leave it burning—that he may ſee the ghoſt.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Wiſh you a good night, Sir.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: A good night's reſt, Sir.—Oh what a clawing will be here by and by.

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p:
For the firſt time indeed, ſince my infancy, I ſhall ſleep under my own roof.—Since I find this Count not here, I ſhall, if poſſible, get out early and meet him at the inn where I appointed.
The dead of night ſeems very awful in theſe antique manſions.—This room was, I think, my dear mother's—yes, there's her picture—my fond parent—

div.stage: Enter ADELAIDE, from a door which opens in the wainſcot—walks as in her ſleep.
div.p: Who's here? a lady!—Heav'ns, ſhe's aſleep!
div.stage: (He ſtands fixed with wonder, Adelaide croſſes, opens a clothes-preſs, takes from her head a hood ſcarf, and night-rail, ſomewhat reſembling the picture in the room, and puts them into the preſs, then, to return to the door where ſhe entered, walks with her face towards Lord Eſmond.)

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: Is it poſſible?—'tis my Adelaide!—Hold! to wake her—the ſudden fright may—yes, this ring, her laſt pledge of affection when we parted— (puts a ring upon her finger, which he had taken from his own). This ring may afford her comfort, without diſcovering that 'tis I that have been here.

This ſeems a private door—and that lobby—yes—it leads to her chamber—ſhe ſtill only knows me for Nugent, and thinks me dead—the cauſe perhaps of her diſordered mind.—To meet her here, my greateſt bleſſing—ſo ſtrange and unexpected! May it lead to ſome greater happipeſs!

div.stage: Exit Lord Eſmond to the receſs.

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: SCENE, Open Country, before a publick Inn, ſign of the Shoulder of Mutton.
Enter MUNS, his horn round his neck, and box under his arm.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: OH that wicked old maſter, to turn me off for only letting in that ſtrange man!—a ſtrange man he was, for none could tell how he got out this morning.—Maſter ſwears he was a thief, and threatens to proſecute me for an accomplice, if I ev'n aſk for my wages—and then I've left my ſweet Mary-gold all to Frill.—Here have I tramp'd two miles, as hungry—and not a ſhilling in my pocket.—Now here's a houſe of entertainment—yet I'm afraid ev'n to ſit down on the bench, leſt I ſhould be aſk'd to pay for it.—I'm ſo hungry—Houſe! (calls faintly) Oh! what an effect an empty pocket has upon a man's voice at the door of a public houſe!

sp.speaker: Landlord.
sp.p: What wou'd you be pleaſed to have?

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Any thing, Sir.

sp.speaker: Landlady.
sp.p: What do you want?

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Every thing, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Landlord.
sp.p: Who are you?

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: A poor ſervant out of place.

sp.speaker: Landlady.
sp.p: We want a waiter, huſband.

sp.speaker: Landlord.
sp.p: Did your maſter give you a character?

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: No, Sir, he had none for himſelf.

sp.speaker: Landlord.
sp.p: What can you do?

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Sir, I don't know what to do.

sp.speaker: Landlord.
sp.p: What are you capable of?

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Oh, Sir—I can play a duet upon the horn.

sp.speaker: Landlord.
sp.p: I want no horn.

sp.speaker: Landlady.
sp.p: No, that you don't, huſband.

sp.speaker: Landlord.
sp.p: You underſtand horſes?

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, and cookery.

sp.speaker: Landlord.
sp.p: I want one in my ſtable.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: A horſe?

sp.speaker: Landlord.
sp.p: Pſha! my ſtable.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, but I'm beſt in the kitchen—Ma'am, I'll do any thing for bread—only employ me—I'll be humble as a ſpaniel—ſecret as a fiſh—watchful as a cat—I'll ſleep like a cock upon one leg, with the other ready to pop down to run on a meſſage.

sp.speaker: Landlord.
sp.p: Come in, my lad, you're the very man for the Shoulder of Mutton.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: That I am, Sir, either bak'd or roaſted.

div.stage: SCENE, a Room in the Inn.

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: Only if Count Fripon inquires for Mr. Nugent, ſhow him in.

sp.speaker: Landlord,
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: Luckily, in the time of my diſtreſs at Montpelier, I took the name of one of their confederates, who, from being ſtationed in a diſtant quarter, probably the Count has never ſeen. They, ſuppoſing me one of their raſcally club, I may get at their ſecret ſchemes, and ſo be prepared to counteract them.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Fal, lal, lal! Ha, Monſieur Nugent, I
never ave de honeur of ſeeing you, but know you are of our club in Paris; Sir, I am rejoice at your coming.

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: Thank ye, Count—I'm ſent—deputed by our friends, to ſee how you go on with my Lord's affairs.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Ah, malheureux! very bad—no money—been out now all laſt night, and got but abuſe—no—dey will pay none but my Lord himſelf—One Jack Connor will not let 'em.

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: Raſcal!—my friendly ſchool-fellow.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Monſieur Nugent—eh—I have de thought—has Monſieur Dowdle, de ſteward, ever ſee you?

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: I think not.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Bon! It vil do—ſince de tenant vil pay none but my Lor himſelf, I vil paſs you on dem for Lor Eſmond, and I warrant in tumble de money, ma foi, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: Excellent! You'll ſay I'm his lordſhip, ha, ha! they pay me, and we return to Paris, and ſhare it with our club, ha, ha! admirable!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Dat is it, ha, ha, ha! But hold—if dey even believe you are he, how will dey tink how you got out of priſon in Paris?—Ah! ah! dat is to be conſider.

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: What do you think of my making my valet paſs for my jailor, whom I'll ſay I prevail'd upon for a bribe to accompany me on this ramble, to ſee my eſtate?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Ay, I'll have him.

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! d'ye hear him?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Diable! dat is he!

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p:
Why, to tell you the truth, I had adopted this very ſcheme of yours, and already
tutor'd my valet to play his part of my jailor.—Now Trap will help me without knowing.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Oh den dis is your valet?—ha, ha, ha! admirable! ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: Now only obſerve how he'll keep up his character.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Oh you're there—I'm glad I've found you.

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: Well, Trap—I call him Trap—

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I thought you'd run away from me; but you frighten me ſo no more, as back you come to priſon directly.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! bravo! Oh he does it capitally!

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: Now I'll give you a ſpecimen how I can act the lord. (apart to Count) But my honeſt jailor, indulge me in this little frolic—I paid you well for it.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Bravo, my Lor; now jailor.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Yes, but what's your pay if I get hang'd for letting you out?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Ah, ah, ah! dat is capital. Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: But I am now going to my caſtle.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: But firſt, my Lord, you'll come back to my caſtle!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Oh charmante! ha, ha, ha! to my caſtle—Oh dat is admirable—ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Yes, damme, what do you laugh at? If I had you peeping through the bars of my caſtle, then you might grin like a baboon.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Yes, but as dere is nobody by, you may now as well drop the jailor.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: But I won't drop the jailor.—Nobody by?—Damme, do you want to reſcue my priſoner, eh?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Begar, if I vas not told you was valet, you almoſt make me tremble.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Valet! what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Oh I warrant he is de careful diligent; I wiſh ſuch to ave de care of my clothes.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Your clothes! ha, ha, ha! I'd deſire only one ſuit and your body in it, I warrant I'd take care of it.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: You will drink my health?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Why, as for your health that's no buſineſs of mine, but I'll drink your wine.—My Lord, I'll have an eye upon you—can he drop from this window?—No, no.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: Well, don't you think we are ſafe in our jailor? Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Ay, I hope you'll play de Lor half ſo vel, and we touch de caſh. Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Do you call, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Ventre bleu! more acting! diable! You Muns, vat bring you here!

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Maſter turn'd me off for letting in, and giving a bed in the haunted room, to a half-ſtarv'd poor devil, that— (ſees Lord Eſmond) Oh! how d'ye do, Sir? La, Sir, did you ſee maſter, coming away?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Den you were at de houſe, eh?

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: Laſt night, to look for you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Oh!—vel, my Lor Eſmond, ven you return to your caſtle as yourſelf—

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: Immediately.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: This my Lord Eſmond! huzza! my fortune's made!

sp.speaker: Landlord.
sp.p: Hey! What have you got lazy already, ſirrah?

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Eh! fellow! who do you talk to? My Lord, had'n't we beſt quit? No accommodation for your lordſhip in theſe paltry inns.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Hey, fellow, you muſt diſpatch all your ſervants and horſes round the country, dat all my Lord's vaſſals and domeſticks may ſhow their duty and reſpect in his welcome home.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: And ſince you did entertain me, to ſhow my gratitude, I open your houſe.

sp.speaker: Lord Eſm.
sp.p: Well ſaid, honeſt Muns; and for your diſintereſted generoſity in receiving me laſt night, you may change places with your old maſter.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Make me ſteward! Oh, my Lord, I ſhall grow mad with joy!—Clear the way there for his lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: The ſtranger one! I ſhou'd have ſtay'd to entertain him but for his reflections on my Lord—and the call of love.

sp.speaker: Phelim.
sp.p: Yes, and here has been old Tough, the grazier, making ſuch a riot about a lamb, he inſiſts has been taken out of his field.

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: Pſha! the fool! never mind him—if my darling will but come, and Father Frank will but marry us—Oh! here comes his reverence.

sp.speaker: F. Frank.
sp.p: Well, Jack Connor, what is this buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: The firſt is, that your reverence will breakfaſt with me.

sp.speaker: F. Frank.
sp.p: Well, that's a buſineſs of no harm, if it be a good breakfaſt.

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: The next, that you marry me to my dear Rachel, who deſigns to ſlip out to me this morning.

sp.speaker: Tough.
sp.p: I will have it.

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: Now here's that litigious blockhead, old Tough, the grazier, come wrangling about—

sp.speaker: Tough.
sp.p: So, Jack Connor, now that Father Frank is here, I'll make my complaint, if you don't reſtore my lamb.

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: She's not yours—you know my ſhepherd ſaw you t'other night ſneak into my field, and brand two of my ſheep with your own name.

sp.speaker: F. Frank.
sp.p: Oh! that was a grievous ſin, neighbour Tough.

sp.speaker: Tough.
sp.p: Ah, Father Frank, I ſee which way your opinion goes where good eating is to be had; but I'll lay my caſe before my Lord's ſteward, that I will.

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: My love!

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Well, here I've run to you. Oh! I'm ſo frighten'd.—Now if you have not brought Father Frank here to marry us.

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! gueſs'd it.—Ah, ſlyone!

sp.speaker: F. Frank.
sp.p: But have you her father's conſent?

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: I've her own, which is worth fifty fathers—eh, Rachel?

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: You have,

sp.speaker: F. Frank.
sp.p: I will not marry you without her father's conſent.

sp.speaker: Phelim.
sp.p: Here's the ſteward.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Lud, my father!

sp.speaker: Phelim.
sp.p: And yonder comes old Tough again, ſwearing he'll complain to him.

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: Will he? 'Gad I've a thought—Ha! (aſide) Father Frank, only ſtep in; Rachel will make breakfaſt for you—ſuffer me to ſay a few words to her father, and I promiſe you he conſents to our marriage.—Huſh! ſtep in.

sp.speaker: F. Frank.
sp.p: Your hot cakes and your eggs are good, and that that's good is the delight of a churchman.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Jack, I am come again to demand your rent, to pay off my Lord's debts to the Count.

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: Well, you ſhall have it, if you'll oblige me.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Oblige you, that's doing all manner of rogueries to the wart and perplex me!

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: Well, my frolicks are all over—for as I loſt every hope of your giving me Rachel—

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: You've no hope indeed—this evening I give her to the Count.

sp.speaker: J. Connor.
sp.p: Well, I knew you would; ſo I ſtruck up to the daughter of old Tough the grazier; unknown to him ſhe has ſcamper'd off here to me, and is this moment in that room.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: No! Well you're a devil of a—

sp.speaker: J. Connor.
sp.p: I am—and how can I help it?

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: You can't.

sp.speaker: J. Connor.
sp.p: We've Father Frank here ready to marry us, but he's afraid of your anger.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: My anger! What is it to me who he marries?

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: Why yes, as 'twas all about my courting your daughter, he will not marry me to this girl without you are willing.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: What! you knave, do you think I'll connive at your running away with any man's daughter! 'Gad, I might be ſerved ſo myſelf.

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: And you ſhall—for by all the beard on your chin, if you don't call to Father Frank, to marry me to the girl within, —there, (points to the room) as I loſe her through you, I'll again tack about, and run away with Rachel in ſpite of your teeth. I tell you, you'll never be able to hold your daughter till I'm tied up.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Then I wiſh you were tied up.—Damn the fellow, he's as dangerous in the village as a fox.—Well, I conſent; ſo call Father Frank.

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: Call a prieſt from his breakfaſt! are you mad?

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Call the wench hither.

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: I will, thank ye— (going, returns.) But I think you'd as good not be preſent.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: No.—Old Tough will owe you a ſad ſpite.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Well, I'm oblig'd to you.—Indeed her father is a wicked old rogue.

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: So he is, Sir; he's a wicked old rogue: why I told him ſo juſt now.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Did you? What! to his face?

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: To his face, as I talk to you this moment.—Says I, you old knave, I'll marry your daughter.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Do, —go in and do it; ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: I will—I'll do it.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I like to ſee a crabbed old numſkull bamboozled, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: So do I, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Tough.
sp.p: I'll have her.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Eh! here he is.

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: Yes, he has miſs'd her. Now only mind the fordid fellow's manner of talking of his family—all in the grazier's ſtyle.—Why, Sir, his wife he calls his ewe.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Then I ſuppoſe he'll call his daughter here within, his lamb, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: Eh! why no; I think he'll ſcarce do that.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: I'll bet you half-a-crown he does.

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: Done! He won't.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: He will. Zounds, don't I know the fellow's mode of phraſe? A mere ſavage!

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: Well, but do you call to the friar.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: I will.—Here, Father Frank, marry the couple directly; go in and do it. (puſhing him in.) Oh! this will make a rare laugh againſt the old fellow, ha, ha, ha! Here he comes.—Father Frank, make haſte and marry them.

sp.speaker: Tough.
sp.p: He ſhall reſtore her.—Mr. Dowdle, do you authoriſe theſe doings?

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: What doings? ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Tough.
sp.p: What doings! Jack Connor to take away my lamb?

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: His lamb! ha, ha, ha! by the Lord I have won my half crown—I knew the grazier would come out, ha, ha! She's Jack Connor's lamb by this, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Tough.
sp.p: His! For ten guineas ſhe carries my name.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! For twenty guineas, by this ſhe carries Jack Connor's, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Tough.
sp.p: Why, zounds! he's not tarring her over again!

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Tarr'd, yes; and ſhe'll be ſoon feather'd.

sp.speaker: Tough.
sp.p: Feather'd!

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Yes, when ſhe's dreſs'd; 'tis all the faſhion, you know.

sp.speaker: Tough.
sp.p: Zounds! then he intends her for his own table.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Yes, certainly, ſhe'll head his table, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Tough.
sp.p: He's plaguy dainty.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Yes, he's a dainty fellow.

sp.speaker: Tough.
sp.p: He's a thief.—I thought to have ſent her to market to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Father Frank, if the job's over, let the lamb come out here, and aſk the old ram's bleſſing.

div.stage: Enter RACHEL, handed in by JACK CONNER and Father FRANK.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Father, your bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Eh! zounds! if this ſhould be the lamb!

sp.speaker: Tough.
sp.p: Egad, and I believe you are the old ram, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Father Frank, what the Devil's this you've been doing?

sp.speaker: F. Frank.
sp.p: Fie, fie! this is unſeemly.—I've been joining this pair in holy wedlock, as you deſired me.

sp.speaker: Tough.
sp.p: As you deſired him, ha, ha, ha! Egad, 'tis my turn to laugh now.

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: Father-in-law, to keep the laugh from yourſelf, you'd beſt join in it.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p:
Father, don't be angry, for upon the
word of a bride, I had no notion of marriage,—but as you deſired it, I complied, to ſhow my obedience.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Oh, plague of your obedience.

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: Sir, father-in-law, here's the half-crown you won.

div.stage: (Old Dowdle breaks from him, and exits in a fury.)

sp.speaker: Tough.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I'm ſo pleas'd. Jack, if you ev'n have my lamb, keep it, and let your lamb carve it for the wedding-day ſupper.

div.stage: Enter MARY, and taps at the door.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Yes, by this my young lady's a bride, and if poor Muns hadn't been turn'd away, I might have been a bride.—Miſs Adelaide! (taps at the door) Bleſs me! will ſhe ſleep all day?

sp.speaker: Adel.
sp.p: 'Tis very late. (Looks at her watch.)

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I ate! ha, ha, ha! now, Miſs, hav'n't you been dreaming of your ſweetheart?

sp.speaker: Adel.
sp.p: Oh! Mary, the ſweeteſt dream!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: La, Miſs, that's a vaſtly pretty ring: I never ſaw you wear it before.

sp.speaker: Adel.
sp.p: Ring! Oh Heavens! is it poſſible?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I muſt put your room to rights.

sp.speaker: Adel.
sp.p:
This is the very ring I gave my Nugent
at our laſt parting! If he ſhould be ſtill alive! Oh tranſport!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: La, Miſs, as ſure as I live, there's a door none of us ever ſaw from your chamber to the haunted room. I went through a long paſſage that goes all the way; and there's my old lady's clothes-preſs open'd, and all in ſuch a confuſion!

sp.speaker: Adel.
sp.p: Do you know of any ſtranger here laſt night?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: None, Miſs, but he I put to ſleep in the haunted room.

sp.speaker: Adel.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Gone, Ma'am, but Lord knows where.

sp.speaker: Adel.
sp.p: It muſt have been my Nugent; every circumſtance confirms it; and this ghoſt muſt have been I that walk'd in my ſleep. I ſhudder to think of the dangers I've eſcap'd; but my Nugent lives, and danger vaniſhes.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Ah, jade! Pray, Miſs, did you know of my daughter's elopement?

sp.speaker: Adel.
sp.p: Dear Sir, did you ſee the gentleman?

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: The Devil's in the women! I aſk about my daughter, and a gentleman is ſlap'd in my teeth! Huſſey, were you her confidant? (to Mary.)

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, can you think where Muns is gone?

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Get along, you jade, you and your Muns; the raſcal, I ſuppoſe, is ſtarving in a ditch by this— (a loud knocking.) Hey! what great man is this?

div.stage: Enter MUNS, in a rich livery.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Hey! nobody to throw open the gates—for us!—Hey!

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: You! you ſcoundrel, how dare you ſhow your ſaucy face here?

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Come, we muſt have the rooms now in ſome order. This table—chairs—ſopha— (with great haſte, and very conſequentially he moves the furniture) We muſt have a total change here—by'r leave—

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Hey! Turn out.

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: Stop—we ſhall ſoon ſee which of us is to turn out.

div.stage: Enter Lord ESMOND (richly dreſſed), and the COUNT.

sp.speaker: Ld. Eſm.
sp.p: My beloved Adelaide!

sp.speaker: Muns.
sp.p: My darling Mary!

sp.speaker: Adel.
sp.p: 'Tis my Nugent!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Nugent! Oh! ſhe vil ſpoil all. (aſide) De lady is miſtake;—dis, Mr. Dowdle, is your maſter.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Eh!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Miſs, ſay with us, and you ſhall ave de much money.

sp.speaker: Adel.
sp.p: And does Mr. Nugent come here an impoſtor? Lord Eſmond has been already too much wrong'd—deprived of liberty and fortune: and, though I never ſaw him, and once dearly loved you (to Ld. Eſmond), could I ſuppoſe you one of his unprincipled oppreſſors, I'd baniſh you for ever from my heart.

sp.speaker: Ld. Eſm.
sp.p: My Adelaide! what joy to prove your probity unſhaken, as your innocence is ſpotleſs! I ſhould ſcarce wiſh to recover my fortune, but to render myſelf more worthy of your love.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: He does act de Lord charmant; I muſt help him on. (aſide) Monſieur Dowdle, I have received lettres from my friends in Paris; to ſhew dere generoſité, dey deſire me to deliver him up his bonds—Dere, my Lor. (gives Lord Eſmond papers.) Now as we have no claim on his Lordſhip, I hope de tenants will now pay dere rents.

sp.speaker: Ld. Eſm.
sp.p: I am ſure, Count, I am vaſtly oblig'd to you for this,

div.stage: Enter JACK CONNER and RACHEL; he with a large ſtick ſtands before Lord Eſmond.

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: I'll die before they take my Lord again to a gaol.

sp.speaker: Ld. Eſm.
sp.p: So, Connor, you'll die for me, and not return to ſup with me? ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: And was it you, my Lord, I affronted at my houſe?

sp.speaker: Ld. Eſm.
sp.p: My old friend, neither time nor dignity has eraſed the affection of our boyiſh days.—As for my ſteward—

sp.speaker: Jack Connor.
sp.p: My Lord, my firſt requeſt is, pardon for my father-in-law.

sp.speaker: Dowd.
sp.p: Ah, Jack! you know how freely I gave you my daughter.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: And I have loſt ma chere Rachel—Ah! malheureux!

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: But now, my Lord you'd as good think of coming back to my houſe.

sp.speaker: Ld. Eſm.
sp.p: I thank you, Trap, but I prefer my own.—Reſtor'd to my eſtate, I will ſatisfy all my creditors; and, be aſſured, I will take care to indemnify you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Diable! Are you really my Lord Eſmond? Oh, I am ruined!

sp.speaker: Ld. Eſm.
sp.p: My ruin, I hope, will teach our nobility, inſtead of travelling to become the dupes of foreign ſharpers, to ſtay at home and ſpend their fortunes amongſt their honeſt tenants, who ſupport their ſplendour—Trap, you have been long my gaoler, now I'll be yours;—but liberty ſhall be your puniſhment—hoſpitality the lock of my priſon—and honeſt Muns my turnkey, to give a welcome to the kind friend, ſocial neighbour, and, above all, the ſtranger in diſtreſs.
